Once you fully contextualise Jewish history, Zionism, and the establishment of Israel, it becomes clear that these events do not fit the definition of settler colonialism. Yet smug racists love using it out of context. 12/12

No Exploitation of Indigenous Labor: Colonisers typically exploit indigenous populations for labor and resources. In contrast, early Zionists emphasized self-reliance, building kibbutzim (communal farms) and promoting Jewish labor. 9/12

Conflict Was Not Preordained: Tensions between Jews and Arabs in the land were not inherent but emerged due to conflicting national movements. Unlike colonial settlers, Jewish immigrants did not arrive with an intent to subjugate or displace. 8/12

Buying Land Legally: The land acquired by early Jewish immigrants was purchased legally from Arab landowners, often at high prices. This distinguishes the process from colonial land grabs or military conquests. 7/12

No Metropole: Colonialism typically involves settlers acting on behalf of a distant empire to extract resources and impose control. In the case of Israel, there was no ‚Äúmother country‚Äù directing Jewish migration. Instead, Jews moved with an idealistic vision. 6/12

Indigenous Status Not Colonial: By definition, indigenous peoples are those with a deep, ancestral, and cultural connection to a land, even if displaced. Jewish ties to Israel‚Äîlinguistically (Hebrew), religiously, and culturally‚Äîalign with this definition, not a colonial one 4/12

Diaspora and Exile: The Jewish people were forcibly exiled from their land by the Babylonians and Romans, leading to a diaspora. The longing to return to Zion has been central to Jewish identity, prayer, and culture throughout history not a colonial aim. 3/12

Jewish Historical Presence: The ancient Jewish kingdoms of Israel and Judah demonstrate a deep, indigenous connection to the land, making Zionism a return to ancestral roots rather than a colonial imposition on foreign soil. 2/12

All of this to say: Zionism was growing and becoming a powerful force in Palestine before the Holocaust, but the Holocaust accelerated the creation of a Jewish state and turned Zionism from a minority movement within world Jewry to a movement with almost unanimous support.

12/13

My point is that anti-Jewish violence in Europe and antisemitic discrimination against Jewish immigrants in the UK and US were a key factor in explaining mass Jewish migration to Palestine. And this contributed to the eventual creation of the Jewish state. 

11/13

But the reality is that in the 30s and 40s, there were few places for Jews to go: immigration to Britain was limited & the US closed its gates to Jews. In fact, the main reason that Jewish immigration to Palestine increased so much in the 1920s was because of the US Immigration Act of 1924.

10/13

3. I don't think it's accurate to say that the Holocaust was a pretext to establish a Jewish state. 

8/13

I believe the Balfour declaration was turned into a sort of mythological moment by the Zionist movement because it needed legitimacy, but in reality it was far from clear that it was going to lead to a Jewish state in Palestine. Until the Holocaust, nothing was assured. 

7/13

And even when the British started advocating for an actual Jewish state (alongside an Arab state, as part of partition plans), they regularly changed their mind and moved back to advocating for a bi-national state or even for an Arab state with a Jewish minority. 

6/13

In fact, the British quickly clarified in the 20s that they didn't mean for Palestine to become entirely Jewish. And they also proposed a wide variety of arrangements that were not a Jewish state (cantons, bi-national state, even an Arab state with a Jewish minority). 

5/13

2. Yes, the Balfour Declaration in 1917 was an important moment for Zionism but by no means it would have, by itself, led to the creation of a Jewish state in Palestine.

4/13

While Zionist power and leverage was definitely growing in Palestine in the 20s and 30s, it's only the Holocaust that gave Zionism the decisive advantage it needed. Without it, it would have likely taken years or even decades more to establish a Jewish state in Palestine. 

3/13

The Russian pogroms of the 1880s, 1903-1906, and 1919-1921, and even the rise of Nazism in the 1930s didn't generate enough support for Zionism to lead to Jewish sovereignty in Palestine.

2/13
